title: Open Philanthropy Project’s Cari Tuna on Funding Global Health
text:
Text size

Cari Tuna, along with her husband Dustin Moskovitz, 35, a co-founder of Facebook and work-management firm Asana, launched the Open Philanthropy Project with charity evaluator GiveWell in 2014. Open Phil, now independent, uses grants and catalytic investments to take risky bets, such as the $17.5 million grant it made earlier this year to Sherlock Diagnostics, which is creating an inexpensive viral diagnostic tool that could reduce the threat of a pandemic.

Tuna, 33, the project’s president, shares her thoughts on their approach to funding basic science in global health, one of their main causes.

How do you select causes?

Choosing which causes to work on is the most important decision a philanthropist makes. That choice plays a huge role in how much good the money can do. We looked at dozens of causes...and we chose our focus areas [U.S. policy, global catastrophic risks, and scientific research] based on three criteria: importance, neglectedness, and tractability.

Importance means how many people an issue affects and how deeply it affects them. Neglectedness means how many other funders are working on the issue. And tractability means whether we can see a clear path to progress; whether there’s any low-hanging fruit. Open Phil published a lot of this analysis on its website, in the hope of helping other donors hit the ground running more quickly than we did.

What drew you to fund basic science in infectious disease, pathogen detection and identification, and countermeasures?

Basic science is an area where philanthropy has a superstrong track record. When we were getting started, we went looking for historical examples of philanthropy changing the world. A couple of examples that really stood out were the development of the birth control pill and the Green Revolution, which massively increased agricultural productivity in the developing world. Those are remarkable success stories, and looking for more opportunities like them is part of what motivates our interest in science.

One way that philanthropy can have outsize impact is by focusing on global catastrophic risks. By that I mean low-likelihood events that could be hugely harmful to human well-being on a global scale, which often are neglected by other funders. Global pandemics represent an especially important and neglected risk. We’ve been investing both in policy work and science to promote early detection and effective responses.

What are you most proud of or excited about in terms of the scientific research you’ve funded?

One of the lessons we learned from studying the history of philanthropy is that basic research can open up whole new areas of science, but it takes a long time to pay off. Philanthropists are well positioned, compared with other actors in society, to invest in work where the benefits are uncertain and far in the future. We’re not looking for, or expecting, quick wins. We’re trying to play the long game, and we’re willing to take risks on things that might not pan out.

Right now, we’re very excited about the Institute for Protein Design’s work on a universal flu vaccine, which just got a big prize from TED’s Audacious Project, and Target Malaria’s progress in its mosquito gene-drive research. If either of these projects succeed, it would do so much good for so many people around the world. We’re proud to have bet on them early.
